To learn more about the threat of sand erosion, and the work I‚Äôm doing to combat this problem, visit my website https://steel.house.gov/sand-erosion

I promised I would get this project done for our community, and I‚Äôm proud to deliver for Orange County. Our beaches are our lifeblood and it‚Äôs critical that they are protected and preserved for generations to come.

In fact, the cities of Newport Beach, Huntington Beach, Seal Beach, and the Orange County Board of Supervisors have requested this funding for decades and have all passed resolutions in support. https://steel.house.gov/sites/evo-subsites/steel.house.gov/files/evo-media-document/Stage13%20Surfside-Sunset%20Beach%20Sand%20Replenishment%20Project%20Letters%20of%20Support.pdf

When I toured the damage, local officials told me that it‚Äôs only a matter of time before the flooding becomes so severe that it poses a threat to human safety. That‚Äôs why the project to restore the sand and buffer the tides is supported by local officials across Orange County.
üì∏In 2020, the so-called ‚ÄúKing Tide‚Äù caused extensive flooding in Newport Beach http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FNgYqgSXsAQW-Fl.png http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FNgYqhPXEAMovQI.png
Not only does the problem destroy our landmark beaches, but it also creates a very real threat of flooding that destroys livelihoods and causes severe damage.

In 1995, after planning the 10th stage of the project, the government abandoned its responsibility to our community, and in 2000, the Army Corps stated that it was no longer budgeting for any future stages in Orange County. This left local communities on the hook to pay the costs

The project took place in stages and was 67% funded by the federal government and 33% funded by local communities. The local share of the funding was *always* covered when it was time for a new stage of the project.

In 1964, the government recognized the problem it had created and initiated the ‚ÄúSan Gabriel to Newport Bay Beach Renourishment Project‚Äù to make necessary repairs and restore the sand. Today, we call this project the Surfside-Sunset & Newport Beach Replenishment Project.
The new construction interrupted the natural tidal process which replenishes sand on the shore, creating narrowed beaches up and down the coastline that were now susceptible to extreme erosion.

In the 1940‚Äôs, the Army Corps of Engineers widened Anaheim Bay & constructed breakwaters & jetties to service the new military bases that opened to boost military efforts for the U.S. Pacific Fleet.

There‚Äôs not a single serious person who looks at Biden‚Äôs actions over the last year (canceling pipelines, discouraging investments, demonizing oil and gas) and thinks the current energy crisis we are in is the fault of America‚Äôs producers instead of this activist administration.

Even without this pressure to divest, investors need certainty to put money into a project. They need to know that they will get a return on the money they invest and that a project will come to fruition.

Biden has purposefully caused regulatory uncertainty to stop investments.

This mostly hurts our small and medium sized producers, who make up a large part of American energy production. The large oil majors will always have the capital they need. The smaller ones, who struggled most during the pandemic, are starving of capital under Biden.

And the capital companies need to actually develop? Biden is actively trying to deny financing of new projects.

Biden‚Äôs agencies issued rules discouraging investment in oil and gas and his banking nominees openly call for the destruction of the industry.

As a result of his original lease ban, there have been ZERO onshore lease sales since Joe Biden took office. And even though the courts have struck down his order, Biden is STILL refusing to have onshore lease sales.
https://apnews.com/article/climate-business-environment-and-nature-91f740cbd9f5f872fcdee911ff5f8026

If a producer can‚Äôt get a lease for a parcel of land (in this case, a federal lease), it creates a gap between the approved parcels and they can‚Äôt drill. 

This is the same for other pieces of the puzzle - right of ways, drilling, environmental litigation. They all must line up.

Here‚Äôs an example of the complex puzzle that has to be solved to drill a well, in this case horizontal drilling for natural gas (fracking).

A producer may have approval for parcels of land highlighted in yellow and blue (state and federal land) and STILL face hurdles. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FNgsUv_WQAkTNMF.jpg

When Joe Biden banned all new oil and gas leases on federal lands, it took away a piece of the puzzle.

If a producer has 8 of the 9 pieces of the puzzle needed to use the permit, but doesn‚Äôt have the last one (the missing lease), they can‚Äôt actually produce anything.

The White House wants you to believe that a drilling permit is the only thing needed for new oil and gas projects. That‚Äôs not true at all. 

It‚Äôs a puzzle of leases, permits, rights of way, and other regulatory bureaucracy. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FNgsUOiWQAYU6Ar.jpg

Let‚Äôs lay out the White House argument, which is just a really poor attempt at political spin.

The argument goes: There are 9k unused drilling permits that are approved. Evil oil companies are refusing to drill with these permits because they want to profit from this crisis.

Remember: Biden‚Äôs presidency began with shutting down an American pipeline (before he green-lit a Russian pipeline). Then he banned new oil and gas leases on federal lands. Then he pressured banks to divest in oil and gas projects.

And now he wants to blame the oil companies?

American energy producers don‚Äôt need an invitation, they need you and your boss to stop pushing idiotic policies that‚Äôve discouraged domestic production for the past year.

The spending bill provides increased funding for @NIH, health care services for veterans, my Scarlett's Sunshine Act to address gaps in our knowledge about sudden infant deaths and $25 million for Pennsylvania's State Opioid Response Grants to combat the opioid crisis.

The bill includes investments in public safety and violence prevention, including the reauthorization of the Violence Against Women Act and funding for local law enforcement training and community violence intervention.

The spending bill includes funding for several programs to support Pennsylvania farmers and preserve the Commonwealth‚Äôs natural resources and outdoor spaces, including conservation programs, abandoned mine land reclamation, energy efficiency, weatherization and more.

This bill is also a win for seniors and people with disabilities by increasing funding for caregivers, nutrition programs like Meals on Wheels, disability employment services and research into birth defects, chronic health conditions and developmental disabilities.

This bill increases funding for child care and early childhood education through the Child Care and Development Block Grant, Head Start, Preschool Development Grants and on-campus child care for parents pursing higher education.

The spending bill builds on the investments of the infrastructure law with $16 billion in additional funding for @USDOT.

That's $16 billion more for roads, highways, bridges, airports & transit. It also makes significant investments in broadband expansion & affordable housing.

The bill increases funding for economic development through @US_EDA, assistance for minority-owned businesses through @USMBDA, community development for Appalachia through @ARCgov, assistance for rural businesses through @usdaRD and job training/apprenticeships through @USDOL.
